questions.text: A 26-year-old male is rushed to the emergency department of a tertiary care hospital in India after being bitten by a snake while working in the fields. He has no significant medical history. On examination, he is anxious, with a bite mark visible on his lower right leg. Within hours, he develops hematuria and laboratory tests indicate a rapid deterioration in renal function. The medical team considers the type of enzyme present in the snake venom that might be responsible for these clinical findings. Which enzyme in snake venom is known to cause hematuria and renal function deterioration?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phospholipase A2

 

Options D:

 

  • Phospholipase A2 is found in pancreatic fluid, snake venom (viper snakes) and in many types of cells
  • It acts on an intact lecithin molecule and hydrolyzes the fatty acid esterified to the second carbon atom gives lysolecithin and fatty acid.
  • Lysolecithin has detergent and haemolytic agent properties causing haemolysis and consequent renal failure

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phospholipase A1 is not typically associated with the clinical effects described.

 

Option B. Phospholipase C can disrupt cell signaling pathways but is less commonly associated with the acute renal effects seen in snakebite victims.

 

Option C. Phospholipase D affects cell membranes and signaling but is not the primary enzyme responsible for the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phospholipase A2 is an enzyme present in snake venom that can cause a broad range of effects, including hemolysis, platelet aggregation, and muscle damage. It can lead to hematuria and acute kidney injury either by direct renal toxicity or through the effects of hemoglobin and myoglobin breakdown products.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 249, DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 106

choices.text: Trypsin is activated by the removal of a hexapeptide from C-terminal end
α 2-Macroglobulin is the major serine protease inhibitor of plasma
Chymotrypsin acts on peptide bonds in which the amino acid C-terminal to the bond is a tryptophan, tyrosine, phenylalanine.
Presence of Ser-His-Asp catalytic triad at the active site

questions.text: In a discussion on the biochemical properties of serine proteases, a molecular biologist outlines several characteristics common to this class of enzymes. Serine proteases play critical roles in various physiological processes, including digestion and coagulation. Which of the following features is universally found in all serine proteases?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Presence of Ser-His-Asp catalytic triad at the active site. 

 

Option D.

 

  • Serine Proteases are proteolytic enzymes with Serine at their active Site
  • Amino acid triad in the active site of Serine Proteases: Ser, His, Asp.
  • Eg: Chymotrypsin, Trypsin, Elastase, Thrombin, Plasmin, Complements and Factor X and XI.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Trypsin is activated by the removal of a hexapeptide from N-terminal end.

 

Option B.α 1-Antitrypsin is the major serine protease inhibitor of plasma. Genetic deficiency of this protein results in emphysema and liver disease.

 

Option C. Chymotrypsin acts on peptide bonds formed in which the amino acid N-terminal to the bond is a tryptophan, tyrosine, phenylalanine

 

Educational Objective:

 

All serine proteases share a common catalytic mechanism that involves a conserved Ser-His-Asp triad at their active sites. This triad plays a crucial role in the catalytic activity of these enzymes, with the serine residue acting as a nucleophile in the cleavage of peptide bonds.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 62, 63.

questions.text: While preparing for a biochemistry exam, a student revisits the classification system for enzymes established by the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (IUBMB). The student focuses on translocases, enzymes facilitating the movement of substances across membranes. In the IUBMB system, under which EC number are translocases classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. EC-7

 

Option D.

 

Translocases are categorized under EC-7, a classification introduced to accommodate enzymes that specifically catalyze the translocation of ions and molecules across membranes or their separation within membranes, distinguishing them from other enzymatic activities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. EC-1: This classification is reserved for oxidoreductases, enzymes that catalyze oxidation-reduction reactions, where one molecule is oxidized while another is reduced.

 

Option B. EC-3: Enzymes classified under EC-3 are hydrolases, which catalyze the cleavage of bonds by the addition of water. This includes enzymes like proteases and lipases.

 

Option C. EC-6: This category is for ligases, enzymes that catalyze the joining of two molecules with the concomitant hydrolysis of a diphosphate bond in ATP or a similar triphosphate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 48, 49.

questions.text: I-cell disease is characterized by a severe lysosomal storage disorder with symptoms manifesting early in life, including developmental delay, skeletal abnormalities, and coarse facial features. This condition results from a deficiency in a key enzyme necessary for the proper targeting of lysosomal enzymes. Without this enzyme, lysosomal proteins fail to be correctly trafficked to lysosomes. Which of the following recognition markers is not properly formed due to the deficiency of the phosphorylating enzyme in I-cell disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mannose 6-phosphate

 

Option B:

 

I-cell disease is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme that adds a phosphate group to mannose residues on lysosomal enzymes, producing the mannose 6-phosphate (M6P) recognition marker. M6P is essential for directing lysosomal enzymes to lysosomes. Without this marker, enzymes are secreted outside the cell instead of being targeted to the lysosome, leading to the accumulation of undigested substrates in lysosomes and the characteristic features of I-cell disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: GM2 ganglioside: This is a component of neuronal cell membranes and is accumulated in Tay-Sachs disease, not I-cell disease, due to a deficiency in Hexosaminidase A, an enzyme unrelated to the defect in I-cell disease.

 

Option C: Galactocerebroside: This is a major component of myelin sheath in the nervous system. Accumulation of galactocerebroside due to a deficiency of galactocerebrosidase enzyme is seen in Krabbe disease, not I-cell disease.

 

Option D: Globoside: Accumulation of globosides occurs in Fabry disease due to a deficiency in alpha-galactosidase A, which is not related to the enzyme deficiency observed in I-cell disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inclusion cell (I-cell) disease is a condition in which lysosomes lack in enzymes but are seen in blood.
  • Mannose-6-phosphate is the marker enzyme to target the nascent enzymes to lysosomes.
  • In I CELL DISEASE, the carbohydrate units are not added to the enzyme → Mannose-6-phosphate deficient enzymes cannot reach their destination (protein targeting defect).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p586

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes fits the definition of a lyase?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aldolase B

 

Option A.

 

Aldolase B is a type of lyase that specifically catalyzes the cleavage of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate into glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate and dihydroxyacetone phosphate in the glycolysis pathway. This reaction involves the breaking of a C-C bond, which is characteristic of lyase activity.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is classified as an oxidoreductase. It catalyzes the interconversion of pyruvate and lactate with concomitant interconversion of NADH and NAD+.

 

Option C. Acetylcholine esterase: This enzyme is a hydrolase, not a lyase. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of acetylcholine into choline and acetate, a critical reaction in the function of the nervous system.

 

Option D. Acetyl CoA carboxylase: This enzyme is a ligase (more specifically, a biotin-dependent carboxylase). It catalyzes the ATP-dependent carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to produce malonyl-CoA, a key step in fatty acid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some examples of Lyases are:

 

  1. HMG CoA Lyase
  2. Argininosuccinate Lyase
  3. ATP Citrate Lyase
  4. Aldolase
  5. Fumarase

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 49.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical research team is investigating a new drug that targets an enzyme involved in the metabolic pathway of a particular hormone. This enzyme is known for its ability to catalyze the rearrangement of atoms within the hormone molecule, effectively altering its shape without changing its chemical composition. Such a transformation is crucial for the hormone's activation and subsequent biological function. Based on the enzyme's action, which category does it belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Isomerase

 

Option D.

 

Isomerases are a class of enzymes that catalyze geometric or structural changes within a molecule, allowing the molecule to be converted into its isomers. These changes can involve the rearrangement of bonds within a molecule, changing the molecule's shape without adding or removing atoms. This class of enzymes is crucial for various metabolic pathways where the conversion of one isomer to another is necessary for the pathway's continuation or regulation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lyase: Lyases catalyze the addition or removal of groups to or from double bonds, or other formations and cleavages of double bonds through means other than hydrolysis and oxidation. They are not primarily involved in isomerization reactions.

 

Option B. Oxidoreductase: Oxidoreductases are involved in oxidation-reduction reactions, where electrons are transferred from one molecule to another. These enzymes are key players in cellular respiration and photosynthesis but do not typically catalyze structural or geometric changes within a single molecule.

 

Option C. Ligase: Ligases catalyze the joining of two molecules with the simultaneous hydrolysis of a diphosphate bond in ATP or a similar triphosphate. They are essential for processes like DNA replication and repair but are not responsible for isomerization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The International Union of Biochemistry (IUB) developed an unambiguous system of enzyme nomenclature in which each enzyme has a unique name and code number that identifies the type of reaction catalyzed and the substrates involved.
  • Enzymes are grouped into six classes.
  1. Oxidoreductases: enzymes that catalyze oxidations and reductions.
  2. Transferases: enzymes that catalyze transfer of moieties such as glycosyl, methyl, or phosphoryl groups.
  3. Hydrolases: enzymes that catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.
  4. Lyases: enzymes that catalyze cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, generating double bonds.
  5. Isomerases: enzymes that catalyze geometric or structural changes within a molecule.
  6. Ligases: enzymes that catalyze the joining together of two molecules in reactions coupled to the hydrolysis of ATP.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 61.

questions.text: Enzyme which cleave C-C bond:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lyase                                                            

 

Option A.

 

  • The International Union of Biochemistry (IUB) developed an unambiguous system of enzyme nomenclature in which each enzyme has a unique name and code number that identify the type of reaction catalyzed and the substrates involved.
  • Enzymes are grouped into six classes.
  1. Oxidoreductases: enzymes that catalyze oxidations and reductions.
  2. Transferases: enzymes that catalyze transfer of moieties such as glycosyl, methyl, or phosphoryl groups.
  3. Hydrolases: enzymes that catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.
  4. Lyases: enzymes that catalyze cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, generating double bonds.
  5. Isomerases: enzymes that catalyze geometric or structural changes within a molecule.
  6. Ligases: enzymes that catalyze the joining together of two molecules in reactions coupled to the hydrolysis of ATP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Oxidoreductases: enzymes that catalyze oxidations and reductions.

 

Option C. Ligases: enzymes that catalyze the joining of two molecules in reaction with hydrolysis of ATP.

 

Option D. Isomerases: enzymes that catalyze geometric or structural changes within a molecule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lyases are enzymes that catalyze the breaking of various chemical bonds by means other than hydrolysis and oxidation, often forming a new double bond or a new ring structure. They can cleave C-C, C-O, C-N and other bonds. For C-C bonds, lyases are the enzymes responsible for the cleavage.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 61.

questions.text: Trypsin is an elastase. State TRUE/ FALSE:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. False

 

Explanation:

 

  • Trypsin is a Serine Protease
  • E.g of Serine Protease includes Chymotrypsin, Trypsin, Elastase, Thrombin, Plasmin, Complements and Factor X and XI.
  • Trypsinogen is activated by enterokinase (enteropeptidase) located on the intestinal microvillus membranes to trypsin → activates other enzyme molecules.
  • Trypsin is activated by the removal of a hexapeptide from N-terminal end.
  • It catalyzes hydrolysis of the bonds formed by carboxyl groups of Arg and Lys.
  • In acute pancreatitis, there is a premature activation of trypsinogen inside the pancreas causing autodigestion of pancreatic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trypsin is a serine protease that preferentially cleaves peptide bonds after positively charged amino acids, such as lysine and arginine. Elastase, while also a serine protease, targets small, neutral amino acids like glycine and alanine.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 63, DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 197

questions.text: Match the following Marker enzyme.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

Explanation

 

  • The Plasma membrane is associated with 5’-Nucleotidase (d), an enzyme involved in the hydrolysis of nucleotides to nucleosides on the cell's exterior.
  • The Endoplasmic reticulum is characterized by Glucose-6-Phosphatase (c), an enzyme involved in glucose metabolism and the gluconeogenesis pathway.
  • The Golgi apparatus is marked by Galactosyl transferase (b), an enzyme critical for the glycosylation processes occurring within this organelle.
  • The Inner mitochondrial membrane contains ATP synthase (a), the enzyme responsible for ATP production during oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 481

questions.text: During a discussion on the role of enzymes within the bloodstream, a medical student is tasked with identifying enzymes that not only circulate in the plasma but also carry out their primary function within the bloodstream. Which of the following enzymes is an example of a functional plasma enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lipoprotein lipase

 

Option A

 

Functional enzymes:

 

  • Plasma contains many functional enzymes which have specific functions and are actively secreted into plasma.
  • E.g: Coagulation Factors and Lipoprotein Lipase.
  • Non-functional enzymes:
  • Plasma also has non-functional enzymes which have no specific function and come out from cells of various tissues due to normal wear and tear.
  • Their normal levels in blood are very low and are drastically increased during cell death (necrosis) or disease.
  • Hence, assays of these enzymes are very useful in diagnosis of diseases.
  • E.g: LDH, Creatine Kinase, Alkaline Phosphatase etc.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Amylase: Although amylase can be found in the blood, its primary function is in the digestive system, where it breaks down carbohydrates.

 

Option C. Aminotransferase: Aminotransferases, such as AST and ALT, are often released into the bloodstream due to liver or muscle damage, but their primary functions are intracellular.

 

Option D. Lactate dehydrogenase: LDH is released into the bloodstream from various tissues in response to cell damage; its main function is not carried out in the plasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is a functional plasma enzyme that plays a crucial role in the metabolism of lipoproteins. It is bound to the endothelial cells of capillaries in heart, muscle, and adipose tissue and is responsible for hydrolyzing triglycerides in lipoproteins, such as chylomicrons and very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL), into free fatty acids and glycerol, which can then be used by the body. Unlike other enzymes that may be found in the plasma due to cell damage or leakage, LPL performs its physiological function within the plasma.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 301.

choices.text: Lyases link two substrates together with the simultaneous hydrolysis of ATP
The reaction Hexose + ATP → Hexose-6-phosphate + ADP would be an example of transferases.
No loss of enzymatic activity on heating
Hydrolases remove one group from the substrate producing a double bond

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the function or characteristic of a particular class of enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The reaction Hexose + ATP → Hexose-6-phosphate + ADP would be an example of transferases.

 

Option B.

 

  • Transferases: Enzymes that catalyse transfer of moieties such as glycosyl, methyl, or phosphoryl groups.

                                             A-R + B → A + B-R

  • E.g. Hexose + ATP → Hexose-6-phosphate + ADP

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lyases: Enzymes that catalyse cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, generating double bonds.

 

Option C. When temperature >> 50°C it leads to heat denaturation and loss of tertiary structure of protein. Activity of the enzyme is decreased.

 

Option D. Hydrolases: Enzymes that catalyse hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N and other covalent bonds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transferases are enzymes that catalyze the transfer of a functional group from one molecule to another. The reaction described, where a phosphate group is transferred from ATP to a hexose molecule to form hexose-6-phosphate and ADP, is a classic example of a transferase enzyme in action. This type of reaction is fundamental in metabolic pathways, including glycolysis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 49.

choices.text: A and R both are right, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A
A is wrong but R is a right statement
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Evaluate the following mentioned assertion (A) and reasoning (R) regarding aldolase and its role in the metabolic pathway

 

Assertion (A): Aldolase is the most common example of hydrolases class of enzyme under IUBMB system of nomenclature of enzymes:

 

Reasoning (R): Aldolase catalyses the step 4 of glycolysis, cleaves the bond in the fructose-1,6-bisphosphate to form glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and (DHAP) dihydroxyacetone phosphate and water is not required for this reversible reaction:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is wrong, but R is a right statement

 

Option C:

 

Explanation:

 

  • Aldolase is an example of lyase group of enzymes, which cleaves the bond without the need of water molecule. Other enzymes include HMG CoA lyase and ATP Citrate lyase.

 

 

STEP 4 OF GLYCOLYSIS; REVERSIBLE

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aldolase is actually classified under the lyases class of enzymes, not hydrolases. Lyases are enzymes that cleave bonds without the addition of water and without the transfer of electrons. The aldolase reaction in glycolysis cleaves fructose-1,6-bisphosphate into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and DHAP without the use of water, fitting the definition of a lyase.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 170.

questions.text: Which one of the enzyme deficiencies is correctly matched with its disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fabry-alpha galactosidase    

 

Option A:

 

Fabry disease involves a deficiency in the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A, leading to the buildup of globotriaosylceramide in the body's cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Gaucher’s d/s- due to deficiency of Glucocerebrosidase.

 

Option C: Cystic fibrosis- a point mutation in CFTR gene results in defective chloride transport.

 

Option D: Chronic bronchitis might result from exposure to acid fumes, Nitrogen dioxide, Sulphur dioxide etc.


Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/ed, pg 193
